0.text:
Translator: Tímea Hegyessy
Reviewer: Denise RQ

5.text: Meditation has been a part of my life.

9.text:
I personally have been practicing it
for the last 5 and a half years.

13.text:
I have been a trainer
for the last 8 months.

15.text:
But I will get into that
a little bit later.

17.text:
My college career has been
unconventional to say the least.

22.text:
I started out as pre-med, got halfway
through my freshman year in college,

25.text:
before realizing
that really wasn't for me.

27.text: I switched my major about 4 times

29.text:
before finally landing
on international studies

34.text:
I think it took me
a long time to figure out

36.text:
what I want to do with my life,
for a few reasons.

39.text:
One, I'd always struggled
with self-confidence,

42.text:
and I would set my standards
for myself so high,

44.text: that anytime I failed to reach them,

46.text:
or I felt I wasn't doing
what I was supposed to be doing,

49.text:
instead of finding strength
from that situation,

51.text: I would beat myself up in falter.

54.text:
Two - my idea of success, happiness,
and satisfaction up until recently

62.text:
We live in a world
that encourages this idea,

64.text:
that in order to be internally satisfied,
we have to rely on external circumstances.

70.text:
This is an idea that's been
hammered into our heads,

74.text:
what happiness, success,
and satisfaction were.

76.text:
Obviously, these are different concepts
for different people at different times.

80.text: It could be the little things

82.text:
like spending time
with friends and family,

84.text: or curling up with a good book;

85.text:
or getting good grades,
getting the job you want,

88.text:
finding the person you're meant
to spend the rest of your life with.

91.text: While all these things are great things,

93.text:
we're still relying on things
outside of ourselves to make us happy.

97.text:
This idea of external substance creation
has been magnified

101.text:
with the increases in technology
and the advent of social media.

104.text:
We can't really exist
without our devices anymore,

106.text: it's almost like our phones have become

108.text:
other body organs
that we can't live without.

111.text:
No offense to anybody,
but I can guarantee,

115.text:
the majority of you will subconsciously
reach for your phone and check your texts.

121.text:
social media has created this idea
of false happiness and satisfaction.

125.text:
Nobody wants to share
bad moments of their lives,

127.text:
none wants to share
their mistakes or their failures.

130.text: So social media has made it seem

132.text:
that everyone is always successful,
and happy, satisfied all the time.

136.text: What if things don't go our way?

137.text: What if don't get the grade we want?

139.text:
What if the person we thought
to spend the rest of our lives with

143.text:
Or we do get the job we want,
but there is a negative aspect to it?

147.text:
Like our boss sucks,
or we have a horrible co-worker.

149.text:
Suddenly, the concept
that was providing us

152.text:
with internal satisfaction,
externally is now negative.

156.text: What I am realizing more and more

158.text:
is that not only is our success temporary
but our happiness is conditional.

162.text: We are only happy or satisfied

164.text:
because something external
is making us happy and satisfied.

167.text:
We are never truly satisfied
for the sake of being satisfied.

171.text:
That's where I realized
I was going wrong.

173.text: Let me back up a little bit.

176.text:
my entire life I had been on
a one-way path to becoming a doctor.

180.text:
My family is filled with
medical professionals,

182.text:
and at age of 5, I declared
I was going to be just like them.

185.text:
Of course, my incredible Indian parents
let out a huge sigh of relief

189.text:
because they didn't have
to convince me to go into medicine.

192.text:
For a long time,
that was what I wanted to do

194.text:
until I started learning more
about myself, my passions, and interests.

197.text:
Suddenly, becoming a doctor
was less of what I wanted to do,

200.text: and more of what I felt obligated to do.

202.text: Because my entire life I have been taught

205.text:
that in order to be successful
you have to be a doctor.

208.text: I was always a weirdly compliant kid,

210.text:
I always knew my parents knew
what is best for me.

212.text:
So instead of being confident
to stand up for myself,

216.text:
Fast forward
to my freshman year of college:

220.text:
I was taking classes that I hated,
and I was doing poorly in them.

223.text:
The person I thought
I'd spend my life with

225.text:
broke up with me
the second he went to college.

228.text: I was still living at home,

229.text:
so I felt like I wasn't having
the normal college experience.

232.text:
After years of having a plan
and a direction for my life,

235.text: all of a sudden, I was lost.

236.text:
When you go through hard times
or through a break-up,

239.text:
everybody tells you to get out,
do things for yourself.

242.text: And I did, I'd hang out with friends,

244.text:
I would go curl up
with a book at a bookstore,

246.text:
I joined our Bollywood Fusion
dance team at school,

254.text:
I would still come home and still feel
internally dissatisfied with myself.

258.text:
Social media became
the bane of my existence.

260.text:
I'd see my friends, my ex,
and all my classmates

264.text:
posting pictures
of their college adventures,

266.text:
their dormrooms, their new friends,
all these new things.

269.text:
I felt like a failure
for a couple of reasons.

271.text:
One - I didn't have anything
to share on social media.

274.text: I was still living at home,

275.text:
I didn't feel like I was having
the conventional college experience.

280.text:
I wasn't meeting the standard of success
that had been dictated for me.

283.text: I wasn't doing well to become a doctor.

285.text:
But because that was all I knew
as success, I stuck with it,

289.text:
and my GPA and my self-esteem
failed as a reason.

293.text:
So how did I change this?
How did I turn my life around?

296.text:
Like I said, meditation has been a part
of my life ever since I can remember.

301.text:
My dad has been practicing
a form of meditation called Raja yoga,

304.text: or yoga of the mind, for over 35 years.

307.text:
My mom started shortly
after they got married.

309.text:
Just like people go to church,
a temple, or a synagogue,

312.text:
meditation is my way of life;
it's all I have ever known.

314.text:
I always knew I was going to start
practicing meditation at some point;

318.text:
I tried it a couple times
at my freshman year of college,

321.text:
but anything at that point that my parents
thought would be good for me,

324.text:
or it would help me get out
of the rut that I was in,

329.text:
Thankfully for me, very luckily,
I have incredible friends,

332.text:
and I have to show off pictures of them,
because they are my whole world.

336.text: I was very lucky to have friends

338.text:
who were not only starting
their college careers,

340.text:
or they were halfway through
their college careers,

343.text:
but they were going through
similar things that I was,

345.text:
and they hadn't built up the resistance
to mediation that I had.

349.text:
One of my friends convinced me to go
to a mediation retreat one weekend.

352.text: At first, I cribbed, and I fussed,

354.text:
I wanted to stay in my own little bubble
of self-pity and misery.

357.text: But in the end, I am so glad I went,

359.text:
because it was probably the best thing
that could happen to me.

364.text:
I'm sure everybody here has a general idea
in their head of what it is,

367.text: but just to give a few more definitions.

369.text:
"Meditation is an exercise
that trains your mind to regulate itself.

375.text:
It's the ability to focus on one thing
continuously without break.

382.text:
it's a consistent reconnection
with your true inner self."

386.text:
A lot of people brush
the concept of meditation aside

389.text:
because we think, "How do we function
without our thoughts?"

392.text:
"How do we get through our day
without thinking?"

396.text:
is just like our bodies
require physical activity

398.text: to keep it strong, healthy, and active,

400.text:
our minds are muscles
that also require exercise and regulation

405.text:
to keep it strong, happy,
healthy, and active.

408.text:
A lot of times, people neglect their minds
because they forget this point.

412.text:
If you think meditation is hard,
you are absolutely right.

415.text:
It is very difficult
to get your brain to shut up

417.text:
for longer five seconds
and not think about something else.

420.text:
That is another reason
why people don't try it out.

423.text: The first time I sat down to meditate,

425.text:
it felt like every single thought I had
ever had in my 18 years of existence

430.text:
decided to come into my head
at that exact moment.

434.text:
No matter how many times
I tried to push them away,

436.text:
ignore my thoughts, or try
to get into a state of thoughtlessness,

440.text: I thought, "Why am I doing this?

442.text:
Another thing in life I am failing at;
why am I even trying?"

446.text:
The second time I sat down
to meditate during that retreat,

449.text: my thoughts decreased by a quarter.

452.text:
The third time I sat down
to meditate during that retreat,

456.text:
Gradually, it was as though I was starting
to see the world in High-Definiton.

461.text:
Not only could I see
my external circumstances very clearly

465.text:
but I was finally starting
to see my true inner self

468.text:
with the objectivity and clarity
that I not had ever before.

474.text:
The practice of meditation
that I am a part of prescribes

478.text:
meditating twice a day
for one hour each time.

482.text:
Once in the morning for an hour,
once in the evening for an hour.

485.text:
I will be totally honest,
it took me a very long time

488.text:
to get to a point
where I was consistent with this.

490.text: Some days I was doing a really great job.

492.text:
I get up, I meditate,
I go to bed, and I meditate.

495.text:
Before I went bed
I would meditate, and I'd be fine.

498.text:
But other days,
more bad days than good days,

501.text: I would just be downright lazy,

502.text:
and I would stay up all night
watching Ellen videos,

505.text:
and then wake up late the next morning
instead of meditating.

510.text:
"I'm young, I have the rest of my life
to work on my meditation practice,

514.text:
I don't have more time
to watch Ellen videos."

517.text:
But I think it took me a long time
to connect with my meditation practice

521.text:
because I wasn't accustomed
to the silence that came with meditation.

525.text: I think. as humans, we thrive on noise

527.text:
because it makes us feel
as we're doing something.

530.text:
So I sit to meditate,
and about 5 to 10 minutes in,

533.text:
I would realize I was craving noise,
I needed some sort of distraction.

537.text: So I'd give up on meditating,

539.text:
and I immediately reached
for my phone or for my laptop.

542.text:
What this taught me was
I had come to point where I hated silence.

546.text:
This also taught me
how loud my world was.

549.text: Noise is not just sound or cacophony,

551.text:
noise is the frustration you feel
with a family member or a friend.

556.text:
it's not understanding
a concept at school.

559.text:
Anything is noise
if it is loud enough to distract us.

562.text:
When I realized
that I'd come to hate silence,

566.text:
it made me examine my routine;
I realized I couldn't get through a day

570.text:
without sound, or noise,
or distractions of some sort.

572.text:
I would wake up in the morning,
and I would meditate half-heartedly

576.text: before giving up because it got too hard.

578.text:
I would immediately reach
for my phone of for my laptop,

580.text: and I would play music and videos

582.text:
while I was getting ready for school
or while I was eating breakfast.

585.text:
I'd drive to school with music on,
I'd get to class, I'd be fine;

588.text:
about halfway through class I'd zone out
thinking about the video I watched.

592.text:
There would be so much chaos
coming around me and in me

594.text: because of my thoughts and distractions

596.text:
that I'd come home
and feel frustrated,

598.text:
and let out that frustration
on my family members

601.text: not knowing what to do with it.

602.text: I'd start my homework and feel frustrated

604.text:
because I wasn't understanding
the concepts,

606.text:
but that's because I had music
on the background.

609.text:
I try to sit down and meditate
at the end of the day,

611.text:
and I'd give up again because there was
so much going on in my head.

615.text:
I get annoyed when I couldn't fall asleep,
and I get frustrated,

618.text:
because I felt like I wasn't progressing
in my meditation practice.

621.text:
What this taught me was in order to create
a true connection with my inner self,

625.text: I had to learn how to love silence.

627.text: In order to learn how to love silence,

630.text:
I had to really use my willpower
and commit to my meditation practice.

634.text:
In order to sustain the love for silence
that I cultivated internally,

639.text:
my internal environment had to interact
with my external environment.

644.text: The more and more I meditated,

646.text:
the more I started to learn
how to love silence internally,

649.text:
the more my internal environment
began to reflect my external environment.

653.text:
That's when I started to see the changes
in myself that I wanted to see.

658.text:
"How meditation creates interaction -
the internal with the external."

664.text:
like I said earlier,
I've always lacked in self-confidence,

667.text:
but creating a consistent reconnection
with my inner self

670.text: drove that fear of confidence away.

671.text:
Suddenly, I was able to
stand up for myself,

674.text:
I was feeling more confident
within myself,

676.text: and it gave me the courage

677.text:
to eventually switch my major
to International Studies,

680.text: and get rid of this idea

681.text:
that in order to be successful,
I have to do something big.

685.text:
Replacing the positive
with the negative --

687.text:
like I said before,
we may get the job that we want,

690.text:
but there is always going to be
something about it that is negative,

693.text: or something, we don't want to deal with.

695.text:
All of a sudden, the entire environment
becomes negative.

698.text:
Cultivating a connection
with my internal self through meditation

702.text:
has allowed me to see
the positive in any situation

709.text:
not just exercise of the mind
but the exercise of the body.

712.text:
When you are taking care
of yourself internally,

715.text:
you are given the ability to take care
of yourself externally as well.

719.text:
Communication --
I seem like I talk a lot up here,

723.text:
but I am actually pretty non-assertive
most of the time,

725.text:
so by creating a connection with myself
through meditation constantly,

729.text:
I was able to say the things
I needed to say,

731.text: speak up for myself when I needed to.

737.text:
being able to create confidence in myself
made me take on challenges

745.text:
it's easier to live in the past,
it's more fun to live in the future,

748.text: but it's better to stay in the moment.

750.text: And that's what meditation does for you.

754.text:
being able to see everyone
as their true selves

764.text:
but if you create the willpower to stop
your brain from thinking long enough,

768.text:
you can pretty much create the willpower
to do just about anything.

772.text:
as corny as it sounds, the more and more
I was able to love myself,

776.text:
the more I was able to love
everything around me.

778.text: There was only one time in my life

780.text:
when I really steered away
from my meditation practice:

782.text:
when I was working on President
Barack Obama's reelection campaign.

786.text:
This is the day my dad and President Obama
went public with their bromance.

791.text:
Anybody who knows
anything about our campaign

793.text: knows that the energy there is so strong

795.text:
that you really don't need
much of anything else to sustain you.

799.text:
I realized I tried to take
the energy from this campaign

802.text: and use it in my daily life.

804.text:
But once again, I was relying
on external circumstances

807.text: to make me feel good internally.

809.text:
I got to do a lot of really cool things
in my senior year of college,

813.text:
I went abroad to study,
a trip to Europe to study Human Rights.

816.text:
I got to be in Wright State's
accredited Model United Nations team,

820.text:
but it became less about
the big things that I was doing,

823.text:
and more about committing
to my meditation practice,

827.text:
making sure that all the values
I created within myself

831.text: were expressed in everything I did,

833.text:
so I did what I was supposed to do
to the best of my abilities.

836.text:
When I was very fortunate to get
the internship with the United Nations,

840.text: I carried that same mentality with me.

842.text: So what I'm learning more and more

845.text:
is that we shouldn't have to rely
on external circumstances

850.text:
True success comes
when you take the time every single day

856.text:
and cultivate the values
you want to see in yourself internally;

859.text:
then, being able to hold
on to those values

862.text:
and express them
in any external circumstance,

865.text: whether they'd be positive or negative.

867.text: One of my best friends, Suraj,

869.text:
actually recently wrote
a blog post about this.

872.text:
We think that changes
come to us as we get older;

874.text:
we think we'll learn how to cook
when we move out,

876.text:
we'll exercise more
when we really need it.

880.text:
We will learn how to cook
when we choose to.

882.text:
We'll learn to work out and exercise
when we choose to work out and exercise.

886.text:
My internal sense of self
didn't change until I made the choice

890.text: to change my internal sense of self.

892.text:
To me, true success is being able
to learn about myself more and more,

896.text:
every single day
with my meditation practice;

898.text:
and using that and expressing it
in any situation that I am put in.
